cont.entity_a: Compatible with Linux. Compatible with various older laptops and operating systems.
cont.entity_b: Compatible with a variety of routers.

cont.entity_a: Requires only driver installation. Easy plug-and-play installation. Installation is straightforward but requires correct driver installation.
cont.entity_b: Seamless installation with Windows. Installation straightforward with provided instructions.

cont.entity_a: Provides solid connections at decent speeds for a Wireless G card. Offers a reliable connection with a good range.
cont.entity_b: Consistent performance and reliability. Good performance and price.

cont.entity_a: Signal strength is low compared to older network cards. Signal strength fluctuates without any user action.
cont.entity_b: Improved range compared to older Linksys cards. Better range and signal strength than built-in wireless.

cont.entity_a: Best speed achieved is 54 Mbps in the same room with the router, and 48 Mbps at a different level and two rooms down. Speed decreases with distance over 100 feet and obstructions like walls.
cont.entity_b: Not as fast or far-reaching as advertised.

cont.entity_a: Supports WPA2 and connects at full G-speed.
cont.entity_b: Occasional need to re-enter WEP key.

cont.entity_a: Not compatible with certain modems due to encryption issues. Does not work well with older operating systems like Windows ME. Not recommended for older systems with limited compatibility.
cont.entity_b: Installation issues with Windows XP auto wireless configuration. Inconsistent performance and connection issues with some laptops.

cont.entity_a: Sturdy and efficient for older laptops.

cont.entity_b: Easy setup and connection in WiFi locations.
Effective for picking up signals from long distances.
